_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



a) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. (TAPI), as a responsible member of the community, fully intends to comply with all applicable Federal, State and local regulations that cover its manufacturing operation in Carolina, Puerto Rico.  To do so, TAPI has established effective programs, set standards and implemented procedures that ensure a safe manufacturing operation and the protection of the environment, the employees, the customers and the citizens of the community where TAPI resides. 

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. understands that responsibility for a Safety and Health program is a compromise between company management and the employees.  TAPI's policy is, and will always be, to provide a safe and healthy work environment. In order to do this, TAPI provides a safe facility and provides the training that will enable the employees to become better professionals. In turn, TAPI just requires that all employees obey and follow the safety rules in place. 

    Management will be responsible for:

1) Developing, updating and implementing the operational procedures and practices that will allow the jobs to be executed in a safe manner

2) Teaching and training the employees on the safety practices to be followed at TAPI and ensuring that employees use the required personal protective equipment.

Employees at TAPI will be responsible for:

1) Obeying the safety rules

2) Participating actively in the company safety programs

3) Notifying management of any unsafe condition in the workplace

4) Suggesting changes and improvements to the procedures

5) Helping in motivating coworkers to work safely. 

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. has communicated and explained to all its employees the health hazards and risks associated with its manufacturing operation and has also communicated and explained to them the policies, procedures, programs and plans that intend

to prevent the occurrence of accidents, releases or disruptions and, in case of an emergency, delineate how to respond to reduce injury to human health and environmental damage. 



b) Regulated substances handled

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. operates a manufacturing facility in Carolina, Puerto Rico in an industrial lot of approximately 6.5 acres of area, owned by International Textile Products International, Inc. The facility is composed of office space, parking lots, aboveground storage tanks, warehouse space, and truck maintenance and washing area. Operation of this facility began in 1980.

TAPI is a producer of polyurethane foam produced by the reaction of an isocyanate group with an alcohol or hydroxyl contributor (polyol) in the presence of water, catalyst and a blowing agent. The reaction is started in a reaction mixer and continued in an open tunnel to allow the expansion and blowing off the heat and gases formed. Blowers installed along the tunnel vent the heat and gases to the atmosphere.

Employees collect the blocks and store them for curing in a designated area of the warehouse. Usually, the foam is ready for further cutting and processing in 24 hours. Production of foam is normally conducted during the morning hours from Monday to Thursday.

TAPI uses a listed chemical that exceeds the threshold quantity established in the RMP regulations (40 CFR 68.130). This chemical is Toluene Diisocyanate (unspecified isomer). 

There are no regulated flammable substances handled in the facility, which exceed the threshold quantity.

TAPI has performed and has documented an Offsite Consequence Analysis for the accidental release of TDI, following the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis document and utilizing the RMP.Comp software for endpoint distance estimation. The report on this analysis is part of this Risk Management Program documentation.





c) Accidental Release Prevention Program and chemical-specific p

revention steps 

TAPI's Release Prevention Program relies on the use of good engineering and management practices, training and a strong preventive maintenance program. The program complies with all applicable federal, state and local regulations for the prevention of accidents or releases of hazardous substances. Some of the actions taken at the facility to prevent accidental release include the following:

* Periodic inspection of storage tanks, lines, pumps, valves, etc.

* Manual inspection of level indicators prior to loading of the tanks to prevent overfilling

* Storage tanks are located inside concrete dikes and sheltered to prevent corrosion.

* Automatic shutoff control systems are installed to safely stop the process in case of electrical power loss or any other abnormal condition.





d) Five-year accident history

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. has had no incidents in its facility involving Toluene Diisocyanate for the past five years that meet the requirements, as defined by EPA in 40 CFR 68.42, for inclusion in the Risk Management Plan.



e) Emergency Response Program

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. has prepared a written Emergency Response Plan that is part of the Emergency Response Program implemented at the facility.  The Plan includes all the federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. This Emergency Response Plan defines the steps to be taken in case of an emergency to in order to reduce hazards and damage to employees, property, neighborhood or environment. The plan names the Emergency Response Coordinators' addresses and home phone numbers and lists the emergency equipment available at the facility for response. New personnel are trained on the contents of the plan and all personnel are retrained on an annual basis.

 Additionally, all employees handling oils and chemicals are trained, on annual basis, on the contents of the Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure Plan, as re

quired in 40CFR112.

TAPI has coordinated and discussed the Emergency Response Plan with the Local Emergency Committee of Carolina (Tel. 787-766-2823) and the local Fire Department. In addition, the Company maintains an open agreement with a qualified emergency response contractor to handle emergencies involving hazardous materials.

















f) Planned changes to improve safety

Tech Aerofoam Products International, Inc. believes, and history has proved, that the programs and plans in place at its facility have been very effective in preventing any accidental release of hazardous substances. TAPI also believes that, in case of a chemical release or another emergency, the procedures developed and implemented by the management of TAPI will reduce to a minimum any harm to its employees, the neighborhood and the environment. Nonetheless, the management and the employees of TAPI continuously keep looking for ideas and suggestions to improve the safety and environmental performance of the company.
